title: Apology to the Courts following the Lowcock report into the Street Trees Dispute

content:
Dear Sheffield City Council,
I am making a formal request for information regarding the apology the Council said it would make to the Courts following the publication of the Independent Inquiry into the Street Tree Dispute by Sir Mark Lowcock. At the Strategy and Resources Committee on the 19 June 2023 the Council accepted in full the recommendations of a report by the Chief Executive that included at para 18 a statement that the Council would apologise to the Courts. Despite my repeated emails asking whether this would be made public and for details of when and to whom the apology has been made, I have received no reply.
I consider the following requested information to be strongly in the public interest given the nature of the dispute, the criticisms by Sir Mark on the Councils ability to be open and honest and the protracted failure to reply to my reasonable requests. It would appear the Council has something to hide in this matter.
The information I seek would be generated in the period from the 6th March 2023 to the date of your response.
I have used the word 'Courts' as this is what the Council used - please take this to mean any Court or Judicial body in regards to an apology.
The information I am seeking is as follows;
1. Has an apology been issued to the Courts and if so, the date(s) and address(es) to which it(they) was sent.
2. The text of any such apology made or a copy of the apology or apologies to the Courts.
3. All emails internal or external relating to the arrangements for, text of, legal opinion or advice about and authorisations for, said apology as specified in the Chief Exec's report of 19 June 2023. Specifically the arrangements were to be overseen by James Henderson and the Chief Exec but may fall to David Hollis (Interim General Council and Monitoring Officer)
4. Are any emails as specified in point 3 above marked as (or not included in your response to this FOI due to being) restricted or excluded from disclosure by way of legal privilege?
5. Have any replies or responses been received from the Courts?
6. Copies or text of any replies received from the Courts.
Yours faithfully,
Paul Brooke

Dear Sheffield City Council,
Please pass this on to the person who conducts Freedom of Information reviews.
I am writing to request an internal review of Sheffield City Council's handling of my FOI request 'Apology to the Courts following the Lowcock report into the Street Trees Dispute'.
Despite repeated reminders I have still not had a reply to my request other than to say I will get a reply.  The subject of my request pertains to a written apology to the Courts. This has now, so I'm told, been sent to the Court but I have not had a copy or any of the information relating to it as set out in my FOI.  I recognized there would be a delay, however the lack of any proper communication is disappointing.
Naturally I may ask for a further review should I be dissatisfied with any answer I do receive.
A full history of my FOI request and all correspondence is available on the Internet at this address:
https://www.whatdotheyknow.com/request/a...
I have additional emails from David Hollis.
Yours faithfully,
Paul Brooke

Dear Mr Brooke
We are responding to your request for an internal review dated 25 January
2024, regarding our failure to reply fully to your request of 29 September
2023, for a copy of the council’s apology to the court relating to an
episode during the Street Trees Dispute.
We uphold your complaint. Your response which was due on 25 October 2023
should have been a “no information held” response. At the time you asked,
we had no material information to provide. It was in good faith that we
sought an extension of the deadline so we could provide information – when
we had created it. As you know, FOI is about recorded information that we
do hold not about information we might hold in the future. We apologise
for your frustration.
Below is your original request with our response.
1. Has an apology been issued to the Courts and if so, the date(s) and
address(es) to which it(they) was sent. Yes. Friday, December 22, 2023
3:32 PM. See response to Q2.
2. The text of any such apology made or a copy of the apology or apologies
to the Courts. Please see: [1]
http://tinyurl.com/363wz3xy
3. All emails internal or external relating to the arrangements for, text
of, legal opinion or advice about and authorisations for, said apology as
specified in the Chief Exec's report of 19 June 2023. Specifically the
arrangements were to be overseen by James Henderson and the Chief Exec but
may fall to David Hollis (Interim General Council and Monitoring Officer)
Attached.
Additionally:
“I do think that the delays on the apology to the Courts are creating
noise that could be avoided,” Extract from an email from a SCC officer to
Kate Josephs, Chief Executive. 16 October 2023 09:13:51
4. Are any emails as specified in point 3 above marked as (or not included
in your response to this FOI due to being) restricted or excluded from
disclosure by way of legal privilege? None.
5. Have any replies or responses been received from the Courts? Yes.
6. Copies or text of any replies received from the Courts. See Q3.
In our disclosure for (3) we have removed SCC staff names below the level
of Head of Service as well as courts’ staff and their direct contact
details under section 40(2) because it is third party information which it
would not be fair to disclose publicly, as it would otherwise breach the
first data protection principle in the UK GDPR.
If you are still dissatisfied with the handling of your request, you can
ask the Information Commissioner for a decision: [2][
email address

Kind regards
